newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian Gevaert to split in reshuffle.
newsitem.headline: Belgian Gevaert to split in reshuffle.

text.p: Belgian holding company Gevaert will be split in two equal parts as part of a major reshuffle of Belgian financial holdings, it was announced at a series of news conferences on Friday.
Part of Gevaert's portfolio will continue under the name Gevaert NV, will be bourse listed, and will have as its majority shareholder Belgian financial holding company Almanij.
The other part of the portfolio will be fully integrated in Belgian holding company Cobepa and will be directly managed by Cobepa.
Cobepa and Almanij plan to partly fund their acquisitions through capital increases.
Existing shareholders in Gevaert will have the choice between acquiring direct stakes in the new Gevaert, or Almanij or Cobepa.
As part of the shakeup, Cobepa unit Ibel will also be split.

Ibel, which is 77 percent owned by Cobepa, said in a statement part of its portfolio would be transferred to Cobepa, the other would be merged into Belgian holding company Belvuco, whose name will be changed to Ibel.
Prior to the operation, Belvuco will carry out a five-for-one stock split.
"The (Ibel) board has agreed the following conversion formula: one Ibel share equals three Cobepa shares, plus one Belvuco share (after the stock split) and a 270 franc gross dividend," Ibel said.
Ibel said it would pay the exceptional dividend before it carries out the operation.
Separately, Belgian holding company Imperial Invest said in a statement it planned to convert all its shares in Gevaert into Almanij shares.
